message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamics on higher-order networks: a review
Paper Abstract: Network science has evolved into an indispensable platform for studying complex systems. But recent research has identified limits of classical networks, where links connect pairs of nodes, to comprehensively describe group interactions. Higher-order networks, where a link can connect more than two nodes, have therefore emerged as a new frontier in network science. Since group interactions are common in social, biological and technological systems, higher-order networks have recently led to important new discoveries across many fields of research. Here, we review these works, focusing in particular on the novel aspects of the dynamics that emerges on higher-order networks. We cover a variety of dynamical processes that have thus far been studied, including different synchronization phenomena, contagion processes, the evolution of cooperation and consensus formation. We also outline open challenges and promising directions for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Epidemic model contagion"

Links: [{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_(epidemiology)"},{"title":"Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases"},{"title":"Complex contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_contagion"},{"title":"Crime contagion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime_contagion_model"},{"title":"Crimson Contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimson_Contagion"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Germ theory of disease - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germ_theory_of_disease"},{"title":"Epidemiological transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiological_transition"},{"title":"Epidemic models on lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_models_on_lattices"},{"title":"Behavioral contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_contagion"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of epidemic models and contagion:

## Epidemic Models

Compartmental models originated in the early 20th century through pioneering work by mathematicians including Hamer (1906), Ross (1916), Kermack and McKendrick (1927), and Kendall (1956).(no content)Epidemiologists and public health officials use these models for several critical purposes: analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting the total number of infections and recoveries over time, estimating key epidemiological parameters such as the basic reproduction number (R0), evaluating potential impacts of different public health interventions, and informing evidence-based policy decisions during disease outbreaks.(no content)The SIR model is one of the simplest compartmental models, and many models are derivatives of this basic form.

## Contagion Dynamics

A common explanation for the growth of epidemics holds that 1 person infects 2, those 2 infect 4 and so on with the number of infected doubling every generation.(no content)This model of an epidemic leads to a curve that grows exponentially until it crashes to zero as all the population have been infected.

## Simple vs. Complex Contagion

Information and disease spread as "simple contagions", requiring only one contact for transmission, while behaviors typically spread as "complex contagions", requiring multiple sources of reinforcement to induce adoption.

Web search results for query: "Network science"

Links: [{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"The Science Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Science_Network"},{"title":"Linked: The New Science of Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked:_The_New_Science_of_Networks"},{"title":"Energy Sciences Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_Sciences_Network"},{"title":"Category:Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Network_science"},{"title":"Social Science Research Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Science_Research_Network"},{"title":"Fellows of the Network Science Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fellows_of_the_Network_Science_Society"},{"title":"Similarity (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(network_science)"},{"title":"Efficiency (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficiency_(network_science)"},{"title":"National Science Foundation Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation_Network"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Network Science:

## Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).

## Interdisciplinary Approach

The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## Development and Key Discoveries

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies, leading to the term 'network science'.(no content)Albert-László Barabási and Reka Albert discovered the scale-free networks nature of many real networks, from the WWW to the cell.

## Applications

Network science has numerous real-world applications across different fields:
- Social network analysis has been used to understand the diffusion of innovation, news and rumors, as well as to examine the spread of both diseases and health-related behaviors.
- It has been used to examine the role of trust in exchange relationships and of social mechanisms in setting prices.
- In criminology, it is being used to identify influential actors in criminal gangs, offender movements, co-offending, predict criminal activities and make policies.

Web search results for query: "Cooperation game theory evolution"

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Prisoner's dilemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoner's_dilemma"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Coopetition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coopetition"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"}]

I've completed a web search on cooperation in game theory and evolution. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Evolutionary game theory can be applied to the prisoner's dilemma game – a game which tests the payoffs of cooperating or defecting from cooperation.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution.

## Key Breakthrough: The "Tit-for-Tat" Strategy

Game theory and evolutionary biology have been used to develop a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals.(no content)The "tit for tat" strategy that cooperates on the first move, and subsequently echoes what the other player did on the previous move, won a tournament by game theorist Anatol Rapoport.

## Success Characteristics

Success in an evolutionary "game" correlated with the following characteristics: Be nice: cooperate, never be the first to defect. Be provocable: return defection for defection, cooperation for cooperation. Don't be envious: focus on maximizing your own 'score', as opposed to ensuring your score is higher than your 'partner's'.

## The Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma

In 1981 Axelrod and Hamilton noted that if the same contestants in the prisoner's dilemma game meet repeatedly (in the iterated prisoner's dilemma game), then tit-for-tat is a robust strategy which promotes altruism. In "tit-for-tat" both players' opening moves are cooperation, and thereafter each contestant repeats the other player's last move, resulting in a seemingly endless sequence of mutually cooperative moves.

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Prisoner's dilemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoner's_dilemma"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Coopetition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coopetition"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"}]

I've completed a web search on cooperation in game theory and evolution. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Evolutionary game theory can be applied to the prisoner's dilemma game – a game which tests the payoffs of cooperating or defecting from cooperation.(no content)Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution.

## Key Breakthrough: The "Tit-for-Tat" Strategy

Game theory and evolutionary biology have been used to develop a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals.(no content)The "tit for tat" strategy that cooperates on the first move, and subsequently echoes what the other player did on the previous move, won a tournament by game theorist Anatol Rapoport.

## Success Characteristics

Success in an evolutionary "game" correlated with the following characteristics: Be nice: cooperate, never be the first to defect. Be provocable: return defection for defection, cooperation for cooperation. Don't be envious: focus on maximizing your own 'score', as opposed to ensuring your score is higher than your 'partner's'.

## The Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma

In 1981 Axelrod and Hamilton noted that if the same contestants in the prisoner's dilemma game meet repeatedly (in the iterated prisoner's dilemma game), then tit-for-tat is a robust strategy which promotes altruism. In "tit-for-tat" both players' opening moves are cooperation, and thereafter each contestant repeats the other player's last move, resulting in a seemingly endless sequence of mutually cooperative moves.

Web search results for query: "Synchronization dynamical systems"

Links: [{"title":"Synchronization of chaos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_of_chaos"},{"title":"Synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization"},{"title":"Chaos theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_theory"},{"title":"Synchronization network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_network"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Swarmalators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarmalators"},{"title":"Graph dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Sequential dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Category:Dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Dynamical_systems"}]

Here are the search results for "Synchronization dynamical systems":

## Overview

Synchronization is an emergent property that occurs in a broad range of dynamical systems, including neural signaling, the heart beating, and the synchronization of firefly light waves.(no content)Synchronization is the coordination of events to operate a system in unison.

## Synchronization of Chaotic Systems

Synchronization of chaos is a phenomenon that may occur when two or more dissipative chaotic systems are coupled.(no content)The systems are said to be completely synchronized when there is a set of initial conditions so that the systems eventually evolve identically in time.(no content)Synchronization of coupled or driven chaotic oscillators is a phenomenon well established experimentally and reasonably well-understood theoretically.(no content)Once the synchronized state has been reached, the effect of a small perturbation that destroys synchronization is rapidly damped, and synchronization is recovered again.

## Synchronization Networks

A synchronization network is a network of coupled dynamical systems consisting of a network connecting oscillators, where oscillators are nodes that emit a signal with somewhat regular frequency and are capable of receiving a signal.(no content)Winfree developed a mean-field approach to synchronization in 1967, which was developed further in the Kuramoto model in the 1970s and 1980s to describe large systems of coupled oscillators.(no content)In the case of global synchronization of phase oscillators, an abrupt transition from unsynchronized to full synchronization takes place when the coupling strength exceeds a critical threshold, known as the Kuramoto model phase transition.

## Natural Examples

Examples of synchronization include the coupled oscillation of Christiaan Huygens' pendulums, fireflies, neurons, the London Millennium Bridge resonance, and large arrays of Josephson junctions.

Links: [{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Consociationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consociationalism"},{"title":"Collective action - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action"},{"title":"Consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory"},{"title":"Consensus based optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_based_optimization"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Consensus sequence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_sequence"}]

I've performed a web search for "Consensus formation dynamics." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Core Concepts

The consensus problem in multi-agent systems aims to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)The consensus protocol, or agreement protocol, defines the rules of interaction that lead to convergence.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.(no content)Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Mathematical Foundation

The behavior of these systems is typically modeled using an unforced dynamical system governed by the network's interconnection topology and the agents' initial conditions.

## Social and Philosophical Perspectives

Consensus models are also used in social and philosophical domains to analyze how groups reach agreement through debate or deliberation.(no content)Network-based methods and social network analysis describe consensus emergence through the information propagation processes of the network (behavioral contagion).

Based on the search results, I can see that the results returned are related to other "higher-order" concepts (like higher-order logic, functions, statistics, and programming) but not specifically about "higher-order networks" as a network science concept. Let me search more specifically for this topic.

Links: [{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_deep_learning"},{"title":"Simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Abstract simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Clique complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clique_complex"},{"title":"Simplicial homology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_homology"},{"title":"Simplicial set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosimplicial_complex"},{"title":"Persistent homology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistent_homology"},{"title":"Talk:Simplicial set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Simplicial_set"},{"title":"Link (simplicial complex) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_(simplicial_complex)"},{"title":"CW complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CW_complex"}]

Based on the search results, I now have information about higher-order networks in the context of network science and topological structures. Here's a comprehensive response:

## Higher-Order Networks

Higher-order networks are structures that process data with higher-order relationships, such as interactions among multiple entities and complex hierarchies, using structures like simplicial complexes and hypergraphs to capture global dependencies and qualitative spatial properties.

### Key Characteristics

While edges in traditional graphs can only model binary relations among entities, in many applications it is desirable to permit relations that incorporate more than two entities, and this idea of using relations that involve more than two entities is central to topological domains.

### Common Topological Structures

Higher-order networks are typically represented using various topological domains:

- Simplicial complexes are the simplest form of higher-order domains that are extensions of graph-based models and admit hierarchical structures, making them suitable for various applications
- Cell complexes generalize simplicial complexes and provide more flexibility in defining higher-order relations

### Applications

Higher-order networks are used in topological neural networks (TNNs), specialized architectures designed to operate on data structured in topological domains such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, which can capture both local and global relationships.

Links: [{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_deep_learning"},{"title":"Simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Abstract simplicial complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_simplicial_complex"},{"title":"Clique complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clique_complex"},{"title":"Simplicial homology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_homology"},{"title":"Simplicial set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosimplicial_complex"},{"title":"Persistent homology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistent_homology"},{"title":"Talk:Simplicial set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Simplicial_set"},{"title":"Link (simplicial complex) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_(simplicial_complex)"},{"title":"CW complex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CW_complex"}]

Based on the search results, I now have information about higher-order networks in the context of network science and topological structures. Here's a comprehensive response:

## Higher-Order Networks

Higher-order networks are structures that process data with higher-order relationships, such as interactions among multiple entities and complex hierarchies, using structures like simplicial complexes and hypergraphs to capture global dependencies and qualitative spatial properties.

### Key Characteristics

While edges in traditional graphs can only model binary relations among entities, in many applications it is desirable to permit relations that incorporate more than two entities, and this idea of using relations that involve more than two entities is central to topological domains.

### Common Topological Structures

Higher-order networks are typically represented using various topological domains:

- Simplicial complexes are the simplest form of higher-order domains that are extensions of graph-based models and admit hierarchical structures, making them suitable for various applications
- Cell complexes generalize simplicial complexes and provide more flexibility in defining higher-order relations

### Applications

Higher-order networks are used in topological neural networks (TNNs), specialized architectures designed to operate on data structured in topological domains such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, which can capture both local and global relationships.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review)

**6 Key Triples Identified:**

1. **Network science** - Foundational concept and field for studying complex systems through networks
2. **Simplicial complex** - Mathematical structure representing higher-order networks beyond pairwise interactions
3. **Synchronization** - Dynamical process examining coupled system coordination
4. **Complex contagion** - Process for studying information and behavioral spreading
5. **Cooperation (evolution)** - Evolutionary dynamics for understanding group interactions
6. **Consensus dynamics** - Process where agents reach agreement through local interactions

All triples have been validated and the JSON file is complete with:
- Correct paper type classification
- Valid Wikipedia URLs 
- Appropriate entity types (all concepts)

- Proper "uses" relations (survey papers use existing concepts)
